title: Commodity markets are in meltdown but Glencore will survive
text:

Wed, Aug 19, 2015, 19:27 BST - UK Markets closed Commodity markets are in meltdown but Glencore will survive By Andrew Critchlow | Telegraph – 14 minutes ago 0.0001 0.0000 
Rout in commodities will claim its victims but there are many reasons why Glencore (Xetra: A1JAGV - news ) can survive better than most 
Glencore’s results were bad but there are still reasons to believe the mining giant will come through the current slump in commodities prices in better shape than many of its rivals . 
The company built by Ivan Glasenberg on the back of big bets on China’s long term demand for raw materials remains the most diversified business in the resources sector due to its sizeable trading division. 
Glencore’s other great strength is its low cost production in key areas of copper, zinc and coal which should allow it to ride out any further declines in prices better than the competition. It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) has indicated that a further $400m can be trimmed from costs in the next 12 months after already saving $392m in 2014. 
Its strong position in high-grade copper production should also allow the company to rebound faster than many of its rivals. Although copper prices have been hammered this year it remains one of the most valuable assets long term for miners due to expected changes in China’s economy that will require more sophisticated raw materials in the future. 
Although copper prices have fallen to a six-year low below $5,000 per ton many analysts expect it to be the first base metal to recover. 
• Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) in Glencore tumble as commodities rout hits 
The company’s share price is worrying but some analysts blame the recent sell off in Glencore stock on investors pricing a potential downgrade of high-yield debt, which Mr Glasenberg will strive to avoid at all costs. 
Certainly, the view within the company is that he has more than enough levers that he can still pull to reduce its net debt pool below $29.5bn and also contend with the prospect of higher financing costs which could follow an increase in US interest rates. 
Despite the concerns over the company’s share price and its debt position, Mr Glasenberg is probably right to hold his long-term bet on China’s economy continuing raw material needs. 
Glencore’s balance sheet has enough flexibility to cope with the current downturn. And, while the current downturn in commodties prices will undoubtedly claim its victims, there is no reason to think that Glencore or Mr Glasenberg will be among them.
